content.en: Today I'm very proud of myself, because I've accomplished something that nobody else has been able to accomplish. I was just informed, while on the helicopter, that our president has finally released a birth certificate. I want to look at it, but I hope it's true, so that we can get on to much more important matters, so the press can stop asking me questions. He should have done it a long time ago. Why he didn't do it when the Clintons asked for it, why he didn't do it when everyone else was asking for it, I don't know. But I am really honored, frankly, to have played such a big role in hopefully, hopefully getting rid of this issue. Now, we have to look at it, we have to see, is it real? Is it proper? What's on it? But I hope it checks out beautifully. I am really proud, I am really honored.
content.zh: 今天我为自己感到非常自豪，因为我完成了一件别人都无法完成的事情。我刚刚在直升机上得知，我们的总统终于公布了出生证明。我想看一下，但我希望这是真的，这样我们就能谈更重要的事情了，媒体也就不会再问我问题了。他早就应该公布了。为什么克林顿夫妇要求的时候他不公布，为什么其他人都要求的时候他不公布，我不知道。但坦白说，我很荣幸能够在解决这个问题上发挥如此重要的作用，希望能够最终解决。现在，我们必须要看一下，我们必须要看看，它是真的吗？它是否正确？上面写了什么？但我希望一切顺利。我真的很自豪，真的很荣幸。

But I don't want to say that because I will get myself in trouble with men. But they haven't figured this out yet but that's OK.

content.en: I want to see a woman president soon, but not [Hillary Clinton]. She's a disaster. She's a disaster. She's a disaster. I mean, just think of the corruption and the scandal... We don't want to go through it. We want to see winning. We want to see win, win, win – constant winning. And you'll say – if I'm president... 'Please, Mr. President, we're winning too much. We can't stand it anymore. Can't we have a loss?' And I'll say no, we're going to keep winning, winning, winning... because we're going to make America great again. And you'll say, 'Okay, Mr. President. Okay.'
content.zh: 我希望很快能看到一位女总统，但不是希拉里·克林顿。她简直是一场灾难。她简直是一场灾难。她简直是一场灾难。我的意思是，想想那些腐败和丑闻……我们不想经历这些。我们想看到胜利。我们想看到胜利、胜利、胜利——持续不断的胜利。你会说——如果我是总统……‘拜托，总统先生，我们赢得太多了。我们再也受不了了。我们不能输吗？’我会说不，我们会继续赢、赢、赢……因为我们会让美国再次伟大。你会说，‘好的，总统先生。好的。’

from.en: Presidential Candidate Donald Trump at Liberty University, C-SPAN (18 January 2016)
from.zh: 总统候选人唐纳德·特朗普在自由大学的演讲，C-SPAN（2016年1月18日）

content.en: Today's ceremony, however, has very special meaning. Because today we are not merely transferring power from one administration to another or from one party to another, but we are transferring power from Washington, DC, and giving it back to you, the people. For too long, a small group in our Nation's Capital has reaped the rewards of Government while the people have borne the cost. Washington flourished, but the people did not share in its wealth. Politicians prospered, but the jobs left, and the factories closed. The establishment protected itself, but not the citizens of our country. Their victories have not been your victories; their triumphs have not been your triumphs; and while they celebrated in our Nation's Capital, there was little to celebrate for struggling families all across our land. That all changes, starting right here and right now, because this moment is your moment: It belongs to you. It belongs to everyone gathered here today and everyone watching all across America. This is your day. This is your celebration. And this, the United States of America, is your country. What truly matters is not which party controls our Government, but whether our Government is controlled by the people. January 20, 2017, will be remembered as the day the people became the rulers of this Nation again. The forgotten men and women of our country will be forgotten no longer. Everyone is listening to you now.
content.zh: 然而，今天的仪式意义非凡。因为今天，我们不仅仅是将权力从一个政府移交给另一个政府，从一个政党移交给另一个政党，而是将权力从华盛顿特区移交给你们，人民。长期以来，我们国家首都的一小部分人坐享其成，而人民却为此付出了代价。华盛顿繁荣昌盛，但人民却未能分享其财富。政客们发了财，但工作岗位流失，工厂倒闭。当权者保护了自己，却没有保护我们国家的公民。他们的胜利并非你们的胜利；他们的辉煌并非你们的辉煌；当他们在首都庆祝时，全国各地苦苦挣扎的家庭却无处可庆祝。这一切都将改变，从此时此刻开始，因为这一刻是你们的时刻：它属于你们。它属于今天在座的每一个人，以及全美所有观看这一刻的人。这是你们的日子。这是你们的庆典。而这，美利坚合众国，是你们的国家。真正重要的不是哪个政党控制着我们的政府，而是我们的政府是否由人民掌控。2017年1月20日，将被铭记为人民再次成为这个国家统治者的日子。我们国家那些被遗忘的男男女女将不再被遗忘。现在，每个人都在聆听你们的声音。

content.en: Today's chemical attack in Syria against innocent people, including women and children, is reprehensible and cannot be ignored by the civilized world. These heinous actions by the Bashar al-Assad regime are a consequence of the past administration's weakness and irresolution. President Obama said in 2012 that he would establish a "red line" against the use of chemical weapons and then did nothing. The United States stands with our allies across the globe to condemn this intolerable attack.

content.zh: 自建国以来，我们许多最伟大的进步——从赢得独立到废除民权，再到扩大妇女投票权——都是由信仰人士引领的。

content.en: So what I would like to recommend is – if we are going to have continued dialogue – we will work out the wall. They are going to say, "who is going to pay for the wall, Mr. President?" to both of us, and we should both say, "we will work it out." It will work out in the formula somehow. As opposed to you saying, "we will not pay" and me saying, "we will not pay."
content.zh: 所以我想建议的是——如果我们要继续对话——我们就应该共同商讨修墙事宜。他们会问我们俩：“总统先生，谁来出钱建墙？” 我们应该都说：“我们会解决的。” 最终会以某种方式达成协议。而不是你说“我们不会付钱”，我说“我们不会付钱”。

content.en: We're going to protect Christianity, and I can say that. I don't have to be politically correct. We're going to protect it. I hear this is a major theme right here, but two Corinthians, 3:17, that's the whole ball game. "Where the Spirit of the Lord", right, "where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty", and here there is Liberty College, but Liberty University, but it is so true. You know, when you think -- and that's really -- is that the one? Is that the one you like? I think that's the one you like because I loved it, and it's so representative of what's taken place. But we are going to protect Christianity. And if you look what's going on throughout the world, you look at Syria where if you're Christian, they're chopping off heads. You look at the different places, and Christianity, it's under siege.
content.zh: 我们要保护基督教，我可以这么说。我不必政治正确。我们要保护它。我听说这是一个重要的主题，但哥林多后书3:17才是关键所在。“主的灵在哪里”，对，“主的灵在哪里，那里就得以自由”，这里提到了自由学院，但自由大学，这千真万确。你知道，当你思考——这真的——这就是那所学校吗？你喜欢那所学校吗？我想你会喜欢那所学校，因为我很喜欢它，它非常能代表正在发生的事情。但我们要保护基督教。如果你看看世界各地正在发生的事情，看看叙利亚，如果你是基督徒，他们就会砍掉你的头。你看看不同的地方，基督教正受到围攻。

content.en: We are very blessed to call this nation our home. And that is what America is: it is our home. It's where we raise our families, care for our loved ones, look out for our neighbors, and live out our dreams. It is my prayer, that on this Thanksgiving, we begin to heal our divisions and move forward as one country, strengthened by a shared purpose and very, very common resolve. In declaring this national holiday, President Lincoln called upon Americans to speak with "one voice and one heart." That's just what we have to do. We have just finished a long and bruising political campaign. Emotions are raw and tensions just don't heal overnight. It doesn't go quickly, unfortunately, but we have before us the chance now to make history together to bring real change to Washington, real safety to our cities, and real prosperity to our communities, including our inner cities. So important to me, and so important to our country. But to succeed, we must enlist the effort of our entire nation. This historic political campaign is now over. Now begins a great national campaign to rebuild our country and to restore the full promise of America for all of our people. I am asking you to join me in this effort. It is time to restore the bonds of trust between citizens. Because when America is unified, there is nothing beyond our reach, and I mean absolutely nothing. Let us give thanks for all that we have, and let us boldly face the exciting new frontiers that lie ahead. Thank you. God Bless You and God Bless America.
content.zh: 我们非常荣幸能将这个国家称为我们的家园。美国就是这样：它是我们的家园。在这里，我们养育家庭，关爱亲人，关怀邻里，实现梦想。我祈祷，在这个感恩节，我们能够弥合分歧，团结一致，共同前进，在共同的目标和坚定的决心下更加强大。林肯总统宣布这个全国性节日时，呼吁美国人“同心同德”。这正是我们必须做的。我们刚刚结束了一场漫长而艰苦的政治竞选。情绪激动，紧张局势并非一朝一夕就能弥合。不幸的是，这一切不会很快结束，但现在我们面前有机会共同创造历史，为华盛顿带来真正的变革，为我们的城市带来真正的安全，为我们的社区，包括内城区带来真正的繁荣。这对我来说如此重要，对我们的国家也如此重要。但要想取得成功，我们必须凝聚全民的力量。这场历史性的政治竞选现已结束。现在，一场伟大的全国性运动拉开帷幕，重建我们的国家，重拾美国对全体人民的全部承诺。我诚邀各位与我携手共进。现在是重建公民之间信任纽带的时候了。因为当美国团结一致时，没有什么是我们无法企及的，我指的是绝对没有。让我们感恩我们所拥有的一切，让我们勇敢地面对前方激动人心的新领域。谢谢大家。愿上帝保佑你们，愿上帝保佑美国。

content.en: Very importantly, you had hundreds of thousands of people come to Washington [on January 6th]. They didn’t come because of me. They came because of the election. They thought the election was a rigged election and that’s why they came. Some of those people went down to the Capitol, I said, peacefully and patriotically, nothing done wrong at all. Nothing done wrong. And action was taken, strong action. Ashli Babbitt was killed. Nobody was killed. There were no guns down there. We didn’t have guns. The others had guns, but we didn’t have guns. And when I say “we” these are people that walk down, this was a tiny percentage of the overall, which nobody sees and nobody shows. But that was a day of love from the standpoint of the millions, it’s like hundreds of thousands. It could have been the largest group I’ve ever spoken before. They asked me to speak. I went and I spoke and I used the term peacefully and patriotically. If you look at the Democrats, what they say, you look at Maxine Waters, and you look at Hillary Clinton and you look at what they say and they don’t put that on. They only put Republicans on, but they couldn’t get me because of the fact that I said, everything’s got to be peaceful and patriotic and we’ll see how it all works out.

content.en: Here with you are over 60 veterans who landed on D-day. Our debt to you is everlasting. Today we express our undying gratitude. When you were young, these men enlisted their lives in a great crusade, one of the greatest of all times. Their mission is the story of an epic battle and the ferocious, eternal struggle between good and evil. On the 6th of June, 1944, they joined a liberation force of awesome power and breathtaking scale. After months of planning, the Allies had chosen this ancient coastline to mount their campaign to vanquish the wicked tyranny of the Nazi empire from the face of the Earth. The battle began in the skies above us. In those first tense midnight hours, 1,000 aircraft roared overhead, with 17,000 Allied airborne troops preparing to leap into the darkness beyond these trees. Then came dawn. The enemy who had occupied these heights saw the largest naval armada in the history of the world. Just a few miles offshore were 7,000 vessels bearing 130,000 warriors.
content.zh: 这里有超过60位在诺曼底登陆的老兵，我们永远感激你们。今天，我们表达我们永恒的感激。当你们年少时，这些将士们投身于一场伟大的圣战，这是有史以来最伟大的圣战之一。他们的使命是一场史诗般的战斗，也是善与恶之间残酷而永恒的斗争。1944年6月6日，他们加入了一支威力惊人、规模惊人的解放军。经过数月的筹划，盟军选择在这片古老的海岸线上发起他们的战役，以将纳粹帝国的邪恶暴政从地球上彻底消灭。战斗在我们头顶的天空打响。在午夜最初的几个紧张时刻，1000架飞机在头顶呼啸而过，17000名盟军空降兵准备跃入树林之外的黑暗中。随后黎明到来。占领这些高地的敌人目睹了世界历史上规模最大的海军舰队。距离海岸仅几英里的地方，停泊着7000艘战舰，载着13万名战士。

I'm not referring just to Russia, but I would certainly put them in that category. And number one, "I hope you're gonna be good anyway. But in those rooms, you have cameras in the strangest places. Cameras that are so small with modern technology, you can't see them and you won't know. You better be careful, or you'll be watching yourself on nightly television." I tell this to people all the time. I was in Russia years ago, with the Miss Universe contest, which did very well—Moscow, the Moscow area did very, very well. And I told many people, "Be careful, because you don't wanna see yourself on television. Cameras all over the place." And again, not just Russia, all over. Does anyone really believe that story? I'm also very much of a germaphobe, by the way, believe me.
content.zh: 记者：一个理性的观察者会认为你容易受到俄罗斯或其情报机构的勒索吗？ 特朗普：让我告诉你我是怎么做的。我离开美国的时候，是个非常高调的人，你觉得呢？我非常小心。我身边有保镖。我周围都是人。我总是告诉他们——无论去哪里，但如果我要离开这个国家，我总是会告诉他们：“要非常小心，因为在你的酒店房间里，无论你去哪里，你都可能有摄像头。” 我指的不仅仅是俄罗斯，但我肯定会把他们归为一类。首先，“我希望你无论如何都会表现好。但在那些房间里，你会在最奇怪的地方安装摄像头。这些摄像头非常小，用现代技术你看不到，也不知道。你最好小心点，否则你会在晚间电视节目中看到自己。” 我总是这样跟别人说。几年前我去俄罗斯参加环球小姐大赛，结果非常成功——莫斯科，莫斯科地区也非常非常成功。我跟很多人说：“小心点，因为你们不想在电视上看到自己。到处都是摄像头。” 再说一次，不只是俄罗斯，而是全国各地。真的有人相信这个故事吗？顺便说一句，我也有严重的洁癖，相信我。

content.en: More powerful than the strength of American arms was the strength of American hearts. They pressed on for love in home and country, the main streets, the schoolyards, the churches and neighbors, the families and communities that gave us men such as these. They were sustained by the confidence that America can do anything because we are a noble nation, with a virtuous people, praying to a righteous God. The exceptional might came from a truly exceptional spirit. The abundance of courage came from an abundance of faith. The great deeds of an Army came from the great depths of their love. As they confronted their fate, the Americans and the Allies placed themselves into the palm of God's hand.

content.en: So I said, ‘Let me ask you a question. Nobody ever asked this question. And it must be because of MIT. My relationship to MIT. Very smart. I say, What would happen if the boat sank from its weight? And you’re in the boat and you have this tremendously powerful battery, and the battery is now underwater, and there’s a shark that’s approximately 10 yards over there. By the way, a lot of shark attacks lately. You notice that? A lot of shark. I watch some guys justifying it today. ‘Well, they weren’t really that angry. They bit off the young lady’s leg because of the fact that they were — they were not hungry, but they misunderstood what - who she was.’ These people are crazy. ‘There’s no problem with sharks. They just didn’t really understand a young woman swimming. No really got decimated and other people too, a lot of shark attacks. So I said, ‘So there’s a shark 10 yards away from the boat, 10 yards or here. Do I get electrocuted? If the boat is sinking, water goes over the battery, the boat is sinking. Do I stay on top of the boat and get electrocuted? Or do I jump over by the shark and not get electrocuted? ‘You know, nobody’s ever asked me that question.’ I said, ‘I think it’s a good question. I think there’s a lot of electric current coming through that water.’ But you know what I’d do if there was a shark or you get electrocuted? I’ll take electrocution every single time. content.en: It's time to remember that old wisdom our soldiers will never forget: that whether we are Black or Brown or White, we all bleed the same red blood of patriots, we all enjoy the same glorious freedoms, and we all salute the same great American flag. And whether a child is born in the urban sprawl of Detroit or the windswept plains of Nebraska, they look up at the same night sky, they fill their heart with the same dreams, and they are infused with the breath of life by the same almighty Creator. So to all Americans in every city near and far, small and large, from mountain to mountain, from ocean to ocean, hear these words: You will never be ignored again. Your voice, your hopes, and your dreams will define our American destiny. And your courage and goodness and love will forever guide us along the way. Together, we will make America strong again. We will make America wealthy again. We will make America proud again. We will make America safe again. And, yes, together, we will make America great again. Thank you. content.en: They were the citizens of free and independent nations, united by their duty to their compatriots and to millions yet unborn. Thank you. There were the Canadians, whose robust sense of honor and loyalty compelled them to take up arms alongside Britain from the very, very beginning. There were the fighting Poles, the tough Norwegians, and the intrepid Aussies. There were the gallant French commandos, soon to be met by thousands of their brave countrymen ready to write a new chapter in the long history of French valor. And finally, there were the Americans. They came from the farms of a vast heartland, the streets of glowing cities and the forges of mighty industrial towns. Before the war, many had never ventured beyond their own community. Now they had come to offer their lives half a world from home.

content.zh: 我最近的当选，是为了彻底扭转一场可怕的背叛以及所有已经发生的背叛，并让人民重拾他们的信仰、财富、民主，以及自由。从这一刻起，美国的衰落结束了。 就在几个月前，在宾夕法尼亚州一片美丽的田野里，一颗刺客的子弹射穿了我的耳朵。但我当时就感觉到，并且现在更加相信，我的生命是被拯救的。上帝拯救了我，是为了让美国再次伟大。 今天，我将签署一系列历史性的行政命令。通过这些行动，我们将开启美国的全面复兴和常识的革命。一切都关乎常识。 我现在站在你们面前，就是为了证明，你们永远不应该相信某些事情是不可能的。在美国，不可能的事情正是我们最擅长的。 我们将勇敢地挺身而出，我们将自豪地生活，我们将大胆地梦想，没有什么能够阻挡我们，因为我们是美国人。未来是我们的，我们的黄金时代才刚刚开始。 从今天起，我们的国家将繁荣昌盛，再次赢得全世界的尊重。我们将成为所有国家羡慕的对象，我们不会再让自己被利用。在特朗普政府的每一天，我都将毫不含糊地把美国放在第一位。

They instead can occupy all of a beautiful area with homes and safety and they can live out their lives in peace and harmony instead of having to go back and do it again. We'll own it and be responsible for dismantling all of the dangerous unexploded bombs and other weapons on the site, level the site and get rid of the destroyed buildings, level it out. Create an economic development that will supply unlimited numbers of jobs and housing for the people of the area. Do a real job, do something different. ... So, by the United States, with its stability and strength, owning it, especially the strength that we're developing and developed over the last fairly short period of time, I would say really since the election, I think we'll be a great keeper of something that is very, very strong, very powerful and very, very good for the area, not just for Israel, for the entire Middle East. ... I do see a long-term ownership position and I see it bringing great stability to that part of the Middle East, and maybe the entire Middle East. And everybody I've spoken to - this was not a decision made lightly. Everybody I've spoken to loves the idea of the United States owning that piece of land, developing and creating thousands of jobs with something that will be magnificent in a really magnificent area that nobody would know.

content.en: This week, we commemorate a mighty endeavor of righteous nations and one of the greatest undertakings in all of history. Seventy-five years ago, more than 150,000 Allied troops were preparing on this island to parachute into France, storm the beaches of Normandy, and win back our civilization. As Her Majesty remembers, the British people had hoped and prayed and fought for this day for nearly 5 years. When Britain stood alone during the Blitz of 1940 and 1941, the Nazi war machine dropped thousands of bombs on this country and right on this magnificent city. Buckingham Palace alone was bombed on 16 separate occasions. In that dark hour, the people of this nation showed the world what it means to be British. They cleared wreckage from the streets, displayed the Union Jack from their shattered homes, and kept fighting on to victory. They only wanted victory. The courage of the United Kingdom's sons and daughters ensured that your destiny would always remain in your own hands. Through it all, the royal family was the resolute face of the Commonwealth's unwavering solidarity.
content.zh: 本周，我们纪念正义国家的伟大壮举，也是历史上最伟大的事业之一。75年前，超过15万盟军士兵在这个岛上准备空降法国，攻占诺曼底海滩，夺回我们的文明。正如女王陛下所记得的，英国人民为这一天的到来，期盼、祈祷和奋斗了近五年。1940年和1941年的闪电战中，英国孤军奋战，纳粹战争机器向这个国家和这座宏伟的城市投下了数千枚炸弹。仅白金汉宫就被轰炸了16次。在那黑暗的时刻，这个国家的人民向世界展示了身为英国人的意义。他们清理街道上的残骸，在破碎的家园悬挂英国国旗，继续战斗，直至胜利。他们只渴望胜利。英国儿女的勇气确保了你们的命运永远掌握在自己手中。在整个过程中，王室始终是英联邦坚定不移团结的代表。

content.en: This beach, codenamed Omaha, was defended by the Nazis with monstrous firepower, thousands and thousands of mines and spikes driven into the sand, so deeply. It was here that tens of thousands of the Americans came. The GIs who boarded the landing craft that morning knew that they carried on their shoulders not just the pack of a soldier, but the fate of the world. Colonel George Taylor, whose 16th Infantry Regiment would join in the first wave, was asked: What would happen if the Germans stopped right then and there, cold on the beach, just stopped them? What would happen? This great American replied: "Why, the 18th Infantry is coming in right behind us. The 26th Infantry will come on too. Then, there is the 2nd Infantry Division already afloat. And the 9th Division. And the 2d Armored. And the 3d Armored. And all the rest. Maybe the 16th won't make it, but someone will."
content.zh: 这片代号为奥马哈的海滩，纳粹用强大的火力、成千上万枚深深扎入沙中的地雷和尖桩严密防守。数以万计的美军正是从这里抵达。那天早上登上登陆艇的美国大兵们深知，他们肩负的不仅仅是士兵的重担，更是世界的命运。乔治·泰勒上校率领的第16步兵团将加入第一波进攻，他被问到：如果德军就地在冰冷的沙滩上驻足，阻止他们前进，会发生什么？这位伟大的美国人回答道：“嗯，第18步兵团紧随其后。第26步兵团也会加入。此外，还有已经登陆的第2步兵师。还有第9步兵师。还有第2装甲师。还有第3装甲师。还有其他所有部队。也许第16步兵团撑不住，但一定会有人挺过来。”

content.en: Seven decades ago, the warriors of D-day fought a sinister enemy who spoke of a thousand-year empire. In defeating that evil, they left a legacy that will last not only for a thousand years, but for all time—for as long as the soul knows of duty and honor; for as long as freedom keeps its hold on the human heart. To the men who sit behind me, and to the boys who rest in the field before me, your example will never, ever grow old. Your legend will never tire. Your spirit—brave, unyielding, and true—will never die. The blood that they spilled, the tears that they shed, the lives that they gave, the sacrifice that they made, did not just win a battle. It did not just win a war. Those who fought here won a future for our Nation. They won the survival of our civilization. And they showed us the way to love, cherish, and defend our way of life for many centuries to come. Today, as we stand together upon this sacred Earth, we pledge that our nations will forever be strong and united. We will forever be together. Our people will forever be bold. Our hearts will forever be loyal. And our children, and their children, will forever and always be free. May God bless our great veterans, may God bless our Allies, may God bless the heroes of D-day, and may God bless America. Thank you. Thank you very much.
content.zh: 七十年前，诺曼底登陆的勇士们与一个号称拥有千年帝国的邪恶敌人作战。在击败邪恶的过程中，他们留下的遗产不仅将流芳千年，而且将永垂不朽——只要灵魂还懂得责任和荣誉；只要自由依然在人心中占据主导地位。对于坐在我身后的那些人，以及在我面前长眠于战场的那些男孩们，你们的榜样永远不会过时。你们的传奇永远不会消逝。你们的精神——勇敢、不屈、真诚——永远不会消逝。他们洒下的鲜血，他们流下的泪水，他们奉献的生命，他们做出的牺牲，不仅仅是赢得了一场战斗。不仅仅是赢得了一场战争。那些在这里战斗的人们为我们的国家赢得了未来。他们赢得了我们文明的延续。他们向我们展示了在未来的几个世纪里热爱、珍惜和捍卫我们生活方式的道路。今天，当我们在这片神圣的土地上站在一起时，我们宣誓，我们的国家将永远强大和团结。我们将永远在一起。我们的人民将永远勇敢。我们的心将永远忠诚。我们的子孙后代将永远自由。愿上帝保佑我们伟大的老兵，愿上帝保佑我们的盟友，愿上帝保佑诺曼底登陆的英雄们，愿上帝保佑美国。谢谢大家，非常感谢。

Altogether, under the Clinton plan, you'd be admitting hundreds of thousands of refugees from the Middle East with no system to vet them, or to prevent the radicalization of the children and their children. from.en: 2 January 2019

content.en: I just want to reiterate, because a lot of people have been asking, well, what would have happened if we did nothing? Did nothing, we just rode it out, and I’ve been asking that question to Tony and Deborah, and they’ve been talking to me about it for a long time, other people have been asking that question, and I think we got our most accurate study today, or certainly most comprehensive. Think of the number, potentially, 2.2 million people if we did nothing. If we didn’t do the distancing, if we didn’t do all of the things that we’re doing. When you hear those numbers, you start to realize that, with the kind of work we went through last week, with the $2.2 trillion, it no longer sounds like a lot, right? You’re talking about, when I heard the number today, first time I’ve heard that number, because I’ve been asking the same question that some people have been asking, I felt even better about what we did last week with the $2.2 trillion, because you’re talking about a potential of up to 2.2 million, and some people said it could even be higher than that. So you’re talking about 2.2 million deaths. 2.2 million people from this. If we can hold that down as we’re saying, to 100,000, it’s a horrible number. Maybe even less, but to 100,000, so we have between 100 and 200,000, we altogether have done a very good job. 2.2, up to 2.2 million deaths and maybe even beyond that? I’m feeling very good about what we did last week.
content.zh: 我只想重申一下，因为很多人一直在问，如果我们什么都不做会发生什么？什么都不做，我们就挺过去了。我一直在问托尼和黛博拉这个问题，他们也跟我讨论这个问题很久了，其他人也一直在问这个问题。我认为我们今天得到了最准确的研究，或者说是最全面的研究。想想看，如果我们什么都不做，可能会有220万人受到影响。如果我们没有保持社交距离，如果我们没有采取我们正在做的所有措施。当你听到这些数字时，你会开始意识到，考虑到我们上周所做的工作，考虑到2.2万亿美元，这听起来已经不算多了吧？您说的是，今天我第一次听到这个数字，因为我一直在问一些人一直在问的同一个问题。我对我们上周用2.2万亿美元所做的工作感到更加欣慰，因为您说的死亡人数可能高达220万，而有些人说甚至可能更高。所以您说的是220万人死亡。220万人因此丧命。如果我们能像我们说的那样，把死亡人数控制在10万，那将是一个可怕的数字。也许更少，但控制在10万，也就是10万到20万之间，我们总体来说已经做得很好了。220万，也就是高达220万的死亡人数，甚至可能更多？我对我们上周的工作感到非常欣慰。

content.en: So we’ve done 1,670,000 tests. Think of that 1,670,000 tests. And we have a great system. Now we’re working with the states in almost all instances, but we have a great system. And the other thing that we bought a tremendous amount of is the hydroxy chloroquine. Hydroxy chloroquine, which I think is, you know, it’s a great malaria drug. It’s worked unbelievably. It’s a powerful drug on malaria and there are signs that it works on this, some very strong signs and in the meantime it’s been around a long time. It also works very powerfully on lupus, so there are some very strong powerful signs and we’ll have to see because again, it’s tested.
content.zh: 我们已经做了167万次检测。想想那167万次检测吧。我们拥有一个非常棒的系统。现在我们几乎在所有情况下都与各州合作，但我们拥有一个非常棒的系统。我们还购买了大量羟氯喹。羟氯喹，我认为它是一种非常有效的抗疟疾药物。它的效果令人难以置信。它是一种强效的抗疟疾药物，有迹象表明它对这种疾病有效，一些迹象非常明显，而且它已经存在很长时间了。它对狼疮也非常有效，所以有一些迹象非常明显，我们拭目以待，因为它已经经过测试了。

And for all we know, this could be the great Trojan Horse. This could be. We don't know who these people are. ... We have to get smart, folks. We don't need the problems — and we've already got those problems, just so you understand. Because they're coming into the country, they're being put where nobody even knows where they are. It's like, if I were the enemy, I would say, I can't believe they're that stupid. They're taking my people and they're putting them all over the place, because you have great military right here.

content.en: Funny how that term caught on, isn't it? I tell everyone, I hated it. Somebody said 'drain the swamp' and I said, 'Oh, that is so hokey. That is so terrible.' I said, all right, I'll try it. So like a month ago I said 'drain the swamp' and the place went crazy. And I said 'Whoa, what's this?' Then I said it again. And then I start saying it like I meant it, right? And then I started to love it, and the place loved it. Drain the swamp. It's true. It's true. Drain the swamp.
content.zh: 这个词怎么就流行起来了，真有意思，不是吗？我跟所有人说，我讨厌它。有人说“抽干沼泽”，我说：“哦，这太俗气了，太糟糕了。”我说，好吧，我试试。所以大约一个月前，我说了“抽干沼泽”，现场一下子沸腾了。我说：“哇，这是什么？”然后我又说了一遍。然后我开始认真地说，对吧？然后我开始喜欢上它，现场也喜欢它。抽干沼泽。这是真的。这是真的。抽干沼泽。

And he had his men load his rifles, and he lined up the 50 people, and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said: You go back to your people, and you tell them what happened. content.en: I want them to try it. It may work, and it may not work. But if it doesn’t work, it’s nothing lost by doing it. Nothing. Because we know long-term what I want. I want to save lives, and I don’t want it to be in a lab for the next year-and-a-half as people are dying all over the place. In France, they had a very good test. They’re continuing. But we don’t have time to go and say, gee, let’s take a couple of years and test it out, and let’s go and test with the test tubes and the laboratories. We don’t have time. I’d love to do that, but we have people dying today. As we speak, there are people dying. If it works, that’d be great. If it doesn’t work, we know for many years malaria, it’s incredible what it’s done for malaria. It’s incredible what it’s done for lupus, but it doesn’t kill people.
content.zh: 我希望他们尝试一下。它可能有效，也可能无效。但如果无效，尝试一下也没什么损失。一点儿也没有。因为从长远来看，我们知道我想要什么。我想拯救生命，我不想让它在接下来的一年半里一直停留在实验室里，因为到处都有人死去。在法国，他们有一个非常好的测试。他们还在继续。但我们没有时间去说，哎呀，让我们花几年时间去测试一下，让我们去用试管和实验室去测试。我们没有时间。我很想这么做，但今天就有人死去。就在我们说话的时候，就有人死去。如果它有效，那就太好了。如果它无效，我们知道多年来疟疾的疗效令人难以置信。它对红斑狼疮的疗效也令人难以置信，但它不会致人死亡。

content.en: America must do more — much more — to protect its citizens, especially people who are potential victims of crimes based on their backgrounds or sexual orientation, as you just saw in Orlando.
content.zh: 美国必须采取更多——远远更多——的措施来保护其公民，尤其是那些可能因其背景或性取向而成为犯罪受害者的人，就像你们刚才在奥兰多看到的那样。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后的讲话（文字记录）

content.en: We have to respect and cherish our police.
content.zh: 我们必须尊重并珍惜我们的警察。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: She’s a CHEATER. She had NOBODY waiting, and the ‘crowd’ looked like 10,000 people! Same thing is happening with her fake ‘crowds’ at her speeches. This is the way the Democrats win Elections, by CHEATING ‒ And they’re even worse at the Ballot Box. She should be disqualified because the creation of a fake image is ELECTION INTERFERENCE. Anyone who does that will cheat at ANYTHING! EVERYTHING ABOUT KAMALA IS FAKE!
content.zh: 她是个骗子。根本没人等她，而“人群”却像上万人一样！她演讲时那些虚假的“人群”也一样。这就是民主党赢得选举的秘诀——作弊——他们在投票箱里甚至更糟。她应该被取消资格，因为制作虚假图像就是干预选举。任何这样做的人，无论做什么都是作弊！ 卡马拉的一切都是假的！

from.en: 12 August 2024, cited in "Trump blames Harris' crowds on AI, so let's all assume everything we don't like is fake!", USA Today
from.zh: 2024年8月12日，引自《今日美国》“特朗普将哈里斯的支持者归咎于人工智能，所以让我们假设我们不喜欢的一切都只是假的！”

content.en: Hillary Clinton wants to empty out the Treasury to bring people into the country that include individuals who preach hate against our citizens. I want to protect our citizens, all of our citizens.
content.zh: 希拉里·克林顿想掏空国库，把那些人带进美国，其中包括那些宣扬仇恨我们公民的人。我想保护我们的公民，我们所有的公民。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后的讲话（文字记录）

content.en: I want to thank the White House Historical Association and all of the people that work so hard with Melania, with everybody, to keep this incredible house or building, or whatever you want to call it — because there really is no name for it; it is special — and we keep it in tip-top shape. We call it sometimes tippy-top shape. And it's a great, great place.
content.zh: 我要感谢白宫历史协会，以及所有与梅拉尼娅以及其他所有人一起辛勤工作的人们，他们守护着这座不可思议的房屋或建筑——或者随便你怎么称呼它——因为它真的没有名字；它很特别——我们一直把它保持在最佳状态。有时我们称之为“极佳状态”。它是一个非常非常棒的地方。

from.en: Referring to the White House, during a speech given for Easter (April 2, 2018)
from.zh: 在复活节演讲中提到白宫（2018年4月2日）

content.en: They all hated me in my first term, and now they’re kissing my ass.
content.zh: 他们在我的第一个任期内都恨我，现在却开始拍我的马屁。

from.en: Trump bragging about how tech moguls have warmed up to him, reported in Trump offers advice to University of Alabama graduates in speech interspersed with politics 'AP News' (May 1, 2025)
from.zh: 特朗普吹嘘科技大亨们如何对他热情起来，据《美联社新闻》（2025年5月1日）报道，特朗普在演讲中穿插政治内容，为阿拉巴马大学毕业生提供建议。

content.en: I see Rick Perry the other day. ... He's doing very poorly in the polls. He put on glasses so people will think he's smart. And it just doesn't work! You know people can see through the glasses!
content.zh: 前几天我见到了里克·佩里……他的民调支持率很差。他戴上眼镜，好让人们觉得他很聪明。但这根本行不通！你知道，人们能透过眼镜看透一切！

from.en: "Trump Campaign Statement on Rick Perry", NPR, 21 July 2015
from.zh: “特朗普竞选团队关于里克·佩里的声明”，NPR，2015年7月21日

content.en: I know words. I have the best words.
content.zh: 我懂词。我拥有最棒的词。

from.en: 30 December 2015 speech in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina reported by Gawker and The Daily Caller
from.zh: Gawker 和 The Daily Caller 报道，2015 年 12 月 30 日，我在南卡罗来纳州希尔顿黑德岛发表演讲

content.en: I like Mexico. And I respect the leaders of Mexico because they're much smarter, they're much street smarter, but they're much smarter and more cunning than our leaders. But you have to see what's going on.
content.zh: 我喜欢墨西哥。我尊重墨西哥的领导人，因为他们比我们的领导人聪明得多，更有街头智慧，也更狡猾得多。但你必须看清现状。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: These events give not only the candidates a chance to be with each other in a very social setting; it also allows the candidates the opportunity to meet the other candidate's team — good team. I know Hillary met my campaign manager, and I got the chance to meet the people who are working so hard to get her elected. There they are — the heads of NBC, CNN, CBS, ABC — there's the New York Times, right over there, and the Washington Post. They're working overtime. True. True. Oh, this one’s going to get me in trouble.
content.zh: 这些活动不仅让候选人有机会在社交氛围浓厚的场合互相交流，也让候选人有机会结识对方的团队——一个优秀的团队。我知道希拉里见过我的竞选经理，我也有机会见到那些为她当选而努力工作的人们。他们就在那儿——NBC、CNN、CBS、ABC的负责人——还有《纽约时报》，就在那儿，还有《华盛顿邮报》。他们加班加点。没错，没错。哦，这可要给我惹麻烦了。

from.en: Al Smith charity dinner speech, 20 October 2016
from.zh: 艾尔·史密斯慈善晚宴演讲，2016年10月20日

content.en: This is the final battle – they know it, I know it, you know it, everybody knows it. Either they win, or we win. And I promise you this: If you put me back in the White House, their reign will be over, and America will be a free nation once again.
content.zh: 这是最后一战——他们知道，我知道，你知道，每个人都知道。要么他们赢，要么我们赢。我向你们保证：如果你们让我重返白宫，他们的统治就结束了，美国将再次成为一个自由的国家。

from.en: CPAC keynote address in National Harbor, Maryland, on March 4, 2023, reported in Five Key Moments from Donald Trump's Crucial CPAC Speech. Newsweek (March 5, 2023).
from.zh: 2023年3月4日，保守派政治行动委员会（CPAC）在马里兰州国家港口发表主旨演讲，摘自《唐纳德·特朗普CPAC重要演讲的五个关键时刻》。《新闻周刊》（2023年3月5日）。

content.en: The truth is, they’re trying to get out of it because she doesn’t want to debate. She’s not a good debater, she’s not a smart person. She doesn’t want to debate.
content.zh: 事实是，他们想逃避，因为她不想辩论。她不擅长辩论，也不聪明。她不想辩论。

from.en: 26 August 2024 in response to the Harris campaign‘s demand that their September 10th debate occur without muted microphones; in "Trump says Harris ‘trying to get out of’ debate over unmuted microphones demand"
from.zh: 2024年8月26日，回应哈里斯竞选团队要求9月10日的辩论取消静音麦克风的要求；摘自“特朗普称哈里斯‘试图逃避’关于取消静音麦克风要求的辩论”

content.en: Can you imagine you’re a parent and your son leaves the house and you say, ‘Jimmy, I love you so much. Go have a good day in school’ and your son comes back with a brutal operation. Can you even imagine this? What the hell is wrong with our country?
content.zh: 你能想象你为人父母，儿子离家出走，你说：“吉米，我太爱你了。去学校好好享受一天吧。”结果儿子回来后却带着一场残酷的手术。你能想象吗？我们国家到底出了什么问题？

from.en: "Trump falsely claims children being forced into gender transition ops at school in rambling fantasy-filled rally speech", Yahoo News / Independent (September 9, 2024)
from.zh: “特朗普在充满幻想的集会演讲中，谎称孩子们在学校被迫接受性别转换手术”，雅虎新闻/独立报（2024年9月9日）

content.en: We're fighting a political correct war. It's a political correct war. I mean, you know what's going on. You know what's going on. These are people that chop off heads. These are people that, in steel cages, drop steel cages into the waters and drowned large numbers of people. These are people that buried people in the sand. We've got to knock them out. I was against the war in Iraq. We shouldn't have been to the war in Iraq. It destabilized the Middle East and I said that was going to happen. But we shouldn't have gotten out the way we got out. The way we got out was insane. And Obama gave a date, and he — and that's how ISIS happened, folks. Hence, the birth of ISIS.
content.zh: 我们正在打一场政治正确的战争。这是一场政治正确的战争。我的意思是，你们知道发生了什么。你们知道发生了什么。这些人砍掉了人头。这些人把铁笼子关在里面，把铁笼子扔进水里，淹死了很多人。这些人把人埋在沙子里。我们必须把他们打倒。我反对伊拉克战争。我们不应该卷入伊拉克战争。它破坏了中东的稳定，我说过这会发生。但我们不应该以我们当时的方式撤离。我们当时的方式太疯狂了。奥巴马给出了一个日期，然后他——ISIS 就是这样产生的，朋友们。ISIS 就是这么诞生的。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016 年 8 月 9 日）

content.en: Those cameras are not going on the move unless we have a protester. If we had a protester that's the only time they move because they're showing something that in their mind is a bad thing, so then they move. But I like that, I've always liked my protesters because the cameras show these massive crowds and people say wow, was that a big crowd.
content.zh: 除非有抗议者，否则摄像机不会移动。如果有抗议者，他们只会移动，因为他们展示的东西在他们看来是坏事，所以他们才会移动。但我喜欢这样，我一直很喜欢我的抗议者，因为摄像机拍到的人群如此庞大，人们会惊叹，哇，那真是一大群人。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: We're not acting clearly, we're not talking clearly, we've got problems.
content.zh: 我们行动不清晰，我们说话不清晰，我们遇到了问题。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后讲话（文字记录）

content.en: We have a dysfunctional immigration system, which does not permit us to know who we let into our country, and it does not permit us to protect our citizens properly. We have an incompetent administration.
content.zh: 我们的移民系统功能失调，无法让我们了解哪些人入境，也无法让我们妥善保护我们的公民。我们的政府无能。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后讲话（文字记录）

content.en: They have put political correctness above common sense, above your safety, and above all else. I refuse to be politically correct.
content.zh: 他们把政治正确置于常识之上，置于你们的安全之上，置于一切之上。我拒绝政治正确。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后讲话（文字记录）

content.en: The days of deadly ignorance will end, and they will end soon.
content.zh: 致命的无知时代终将终结，而且很快就会终结。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后讲话（文字记录）

content.en: Immigration is a privilege, and we should not let anyone into this country who doesn't support our communities. All of our communities, every single one of them.
content.zh: 移民是一种特权，我们不应该让任何不支持我们社区的人进入这个国家。我们所有的社区，每一个社区。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后的讲话（文字记录）

content.en: The last major NATO mission was Hillary Clinton's war in Libya. That mission helped to unleash ISIS on a new continent.
content.zh: 北约上一次重大行动是希拉里·克林顿在利比亚的战争。那次行动帮助ISIS在新大陆上肆虐。

from.en: Speech after the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting (transcript)
from.zh: 2016年奥兰多夜总会枪击案后讲话（文字记录）

content.en: The fundamental problem with the immigration system in our country is that it serves the needs of wealthy donors, political activists and powerful politicians. Let me tell you who it doesn’t serve: it doesn’t serve you, the American people.
content.zh: 我们国家移民制度的根本问题在于，它服务于富有的捐赠者、政治活动家和权势显赫的政客的需求。让我来告诉你，它不服务谁：它不服务你们，美国人民。

from.en: Immigration speech, Arizona (31 August 2016)
from.zh: 亚利桑那州移民演讲（2016年8月31日）

content.en: To all the politicians, donors and special interests, hear these words from me today: there is only one core issue in the immigration debate and it is this: the well-being of the American people. Nothing even comes a close second.
content.zh: 各位政客、捐赠者和特殊利益集团，今天请听我说：移民辩论的核心议题只有一个：美国人民的福祉。没有什么比这更重要。

from.en: Immigration speech, Arizona (31 August 2016)
from.zh: 亚利桑那州移民演讲（2016年8月31日）

content.en: What's going on in this country is insane. And we have people running our country that don't know what they're doing, they're grossly incompetent, and it's time. We have to make change, real change. Not Obama change, we have to make change.
content.zh: 这个国家正在发生的事情简直疯狂。我们国家治理者们浑然不知自己在做什么，极其无能，是时候了。我们必须做出改变，真正的改变。不是奥巴马式的改变，我们必须做出改变。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: Remember Obamacare, "you're going to keep your doctor, you're going to keep your plan, over and over again, you're going to keep your doctor." It was a lie. And in fact, if he didn't make the lie, he would have never gotten it approved because most Democrats, many of the Democrats didn't want to do it. It was only that, that got them to sign it and to approve it. And it was a lie.
content.zh: 记住奥巴马医改，“你要保留你的医生，你要保留你的计划，一遍又一遍，你要保留你的医生。” 这根本就是个谎言。事实上，如果他不撒谎，它就永远不会获得批准，因为大多数民主党人，很多民主党人都不想这么做。正是因为这个，他们才签署并批准了它。这根本就是个谎言。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: 33,000 e-mails are missing. And she's so guilty. She's so guilty.
content.zh: 33000封电子邮件丢失了。她真的太内疚了。她真的太内疚了。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: Could you imagine if I said that "I short circuited"? They would be calling for my execution, — electric chair. They'd bring back the electric chair. It would be a whole different ball game if I said it, believe me.
content.zh: 你能想象如果我说“我短路了”会怎么样吗？他们会要求处决我——电椅。他们会恢复电椅制度。如果我这么说，那情况就完全不同了，相信我。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: I see the carnage that NAFTA has caused, I see the carnage. It's been horrible. ... It's a suicidal pact for our country. And you know I've watched for years.
content.zh: 我亲眼目睹了北美自由贸易协定造成的惨痛后果，我亲眼目睹了这一切。这太可怕了……这对我们国家来说无异于自杀。你知道，我已经注视了好几年了。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: Today, homeownership is at its lowest rate in 51 years. ... Lowest that its been in so many years, 51 years. Nearly 12 million people and more Americans are dependent on food stamps and 2 million more Latino Americans live in poverty under Obama and Clinton — under Obama; because Clinton's just gonna carry on.
content.zh: 如今，房屋自有率已降至51年来的最低水平……这是多年来，51年来的最低水平。在奥巴马和克林顿执政期间，近1200万甚至更多的美国人依赖食品券，还有200多万拉美裔美国人生活在贫困之中——在奥巴马执政期间；因为克林顿还会继续执政。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: If she gets to pick her judges, nothing you can do, folks. Although the Second Amendment people, maybe there is. I don't know. But — but I'll tell you what. That will be a horrible day. If — if Hillary gets to put her judges — right now, we're tied. You see what's going on.
content.zh: 如果她能自己挑选法官，各位，你们就无能为力了。不过，第二修正案的支持者们，或许可以。我不知道。但是——但我告诉你，那将是糟糕的一天。如果——如果希拉里现在能自己挑选法官——那我们势均力敌了。你们明白发生了什么。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: Hillary essentially wants to abolish the Second Amendment.
content.zh: 希拉里本质上是想废除第二修正案。

from.en: Speech at rally in Wilmington, North Carolina. Transcript (August 9, 2016)
from.zh: 北卡罗来纳州威尔明顿集会演讲。文字记录（2016年8月9日）

content.en: We can't have someone in the Oval Office who doesn't understand the meaning of the word "confidential" or "classified".
content.zh: 我们不能让一个不懂“机密”或“机密”含义的人入主椭圆形办公室。

from.en: Trump campaign speech in Greenville, North Carolina (6 September 2016)
from.zh: 特朗普在北卡罗来纳州格林维尔的竞选演讲（2016年9月6日）

content.en: While my opponent slanders you as deplorable... I call you hard-working, American patriots.
content.zh: 当我的对手诽谤你们可悲时……我称你们为勤劳的美国爱国者。

from.en: Donald Trump Campaign Rally in Ashville, North Carolina, C-SPAN.org (12 September 2016).
from.zh: 唐纳德·特朗普在北卡罗来纳州阿什维尔的竞选集会，C-SPAN.org（2016年9月12日）。

content.en: Hillary is so corrupt, she got kicked off the Watergate commission.
content.zh: 希拉里腐败透顶，她被水门事件委员会开除了。

from.en: Al Smith charity dinner speech, 20 October 2016
from.zh: 艾尔·史密斯慈善晚宴演讲，2016年10月20日

content.en: No dream is too big, no challenge is too great. Nothing we want for our future is beyond our reach. America will no longer settle for anything less than the best.
content.zh: 没有梦想无法实现，没有挑战无法克服。我们对未来的期盼，无所不能。美国将不再满足于任何次等的事物。

from.en: Victory Speech (9 November 2016)
from.zh: 胜利演讲（2016年11月9日）

content.en: Nothing is easier or more pathetic than being a critic. Because they're people that can't get the job done. But the future belongs to the dreamers, not to the critics. The future belongs to the people who follow their heart no matter what the critics say.
content.zh: 没有什么比做批评家更容易，也最可悲了。因为他们根本无法完成工作。但未来属于梦想家，而不是批评家。未来属于那些无论批评家怎么说都坚持自己内心的人。

from.en: Liberty University commencement speech (13 May 2017)
from.zh: 自由大学毕业典礼演讲（2017年5月13日）

content.en: We’re not going back to people that want to destroy our great Social Security system – even some in our own party; I wonder who that might be – who want to raise the minimum age of Social Security to 70, 75 or even 80 in some cases, and who are out to cut Medicare to a level that will be unrecognizable
content.zh: 我们不会回到那些想要摧毁我们伟大的社会保障体系的人身边——即使我们党内也有人这么做；我想知道这些人会是谁——他们想把社会保障的最低年龄提高到70岁、75岁，在某些情况下甚至80岁，他们想把医疗保险削减到令人无法辨认的水平。

content.en: I will totally obliterate the deep state. I will fire the unelected bureaucrats and shadow forces who have weaponized our justice system like it has never been weaponized before. And I will put the people back in charge of this country again.
content.zh: 我将彻底摧毁“深层政府”。我将解雇那些将我们的司法系统前所未有地武器化的未经选举的官僚和影子势力。我将让人民重新掌控这个国家。

content.en: We pledge to you that we will root out the Communists, Marxists, Fascists, and Radical Left Thugs that live like vermin within the confines of our Country, lie, steal, and cheat on Elections, and will do anything possible, whether legally or illegally, to destroy America, and the American Dream. The threat from outside forces is far less sinister, dangerous, and grave, than the threat from within. Despite the hatred and anger of the Radical Left Lunatics who want to destroy our Country, we will MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!
content.zh: 我们向你们保证，我们将铲除那些在我们国家境内肆虐、撒谎、盗窃、欺骗选举、不择手段摧毁美国和美国梦的共产主义者、马克思主义者、法西斯主义者和激进左翼暴徒。他们不择手段，无论合法还是非法，不择手段。外部威胁远不如内部威胁险恶、危险和严重。尽管那些想要摧毁我们国家的激进左翼疯子充满仇恨和愤怒，但我们会让美国再次伟大！

content.en: Bye bye. Look, see? He's smiling. See, he's having a good time. Oh, I love the old days, you know? You know what I hate? There's a guy, totally disruptive, throwing punches, we're not allowed to punch back anymore. I love the old days. You know what they used to do to guys like that when they were in a place like this? They'd be carried out on a stretcher, folks. You know, I love our police, and I really respect our police, and they're not getting enough. They're not. Honestly, I hate to see that. Here's a guy, throwing punches, nasty as hell, screaming at everything else when we're talking, and he's walking out, and we're not allowed -- you know, the guards are very gentle with him, he's walking out, like, big high fives, smiling, laughing -- I'd like to punch him in the face, I'll tell you.
content.zh: 再见。你看，看到了吗？他笑了。看，他玩得正开心。哦，我爱过去的日子，你知道吗？你知道我讨厌什么吗？有个家伙，非常捣乱，挥拳打人，我们再也不被允许还手了。我爱过去的日子。你知道以前在这种地方，他们会怎么对付这种人吗？他们会被担架抬出去，伙计们。你知道，我爱我们的警察，我非常尊重我们的警察，但他们得不到应有的尊重。他们得不到应有的尊重。说实话，我讨厌看到那样的情况。有个家伙，挥拳打人，态度恶劣，在我们说话的时候对着其他东西大喊大叫，然后他走了出去，我们不允许——你知道，警卫对他很温柔，他走了出去，就像，大大地击掌，微笑着，大笑着——我真想揍他一顿，我跟你说。

content.en: Nine thousand three hundred and eighty-eight young Americans rest beneath the white crosses and Stars of David arrayed on these beautiful grounds. Each one has been adopted by a French family that thinks of him as their own. They come from all over France to look after our boys. They kneel. They cry. They pray. They place flowers. And they never forget. Today America embraces the French people and thanks you for honoring our beloved dead. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
content.zh: 九千三百八十八名美国青年，长眠于这片美丽的土地上，安息于白色十字架和大卫之星的映衬之下。他们每个人都被一个法国家庭收养，并视他们为自己的亲人。他们从法国各地赶来，照顾我们的孩子们。他们下跪，他们哭泣，他们祈祷，他们献上鲜花。他们永志不忘。今天，美国拥抱法国人民，感谢你们缅怀我们挚爱的逝者。谢谢！谢谢！谢谢！

[It's] so simple. It's like the paper clip.

content.en: What do you have to lose? What do you have to lose? And a lot of people are saying that when … and are taking it, if you’re a doctor, a nurse, a first responder, a medical person going into hospitals, they say taking it before the fact is good, but what do you have to lose? They say, take it, I’m not looking at it one way or the other, but we want to get out of this. If it does work, it would be a shame if we didn’t do it early. But we have some very good signs. So that’s hydroxy chloroquine and as azithromycin, and again, you have to go through your medical people get the approval. But I’ve seen things that I sort of like, so what do I know? I’m not a doctor, I’m not a doctor, but I have common sense.
content.zh: 你有什么可失去的？你有什么可失去的？很多人说，如果你是医生、护士、急救人员、去医院的医务人员，并且正在服用某种药物，他们会说在疫情爆发前服用是好的，但你有什么可失去的呢？他们说，服用吧，我对此并无异议，但我们想摆脱困境。如果它真的有效，如果我们不及早使用，那真是太可惜了。不过，我们已经看到了一些非常好的迹象。比如羟氯喹和阿奇霉素，同样，你必须经过医务人员的批准。但我见过一些我有点喜欢的东西，所以我知道什么呢？我不是医生，我不是医生，但我有常识。

content.en: The FDA feels good about it. They’ve, as you know, they’ve approved it. They gave it a rapid approved approval. And the reason because it’s been out there for a long time and they know the side effects and they also know the potential. So based on that, we have sent it throughout the country. We have it stockpiled about 29 million doses, 29 million doses. We have a lot of it. We hope it works. Driven by the goal of the brightest minds in science. We have the brightest minds in science, but we were driven by the goal of getting rid of this plague, getting rid of this scourge, getting rid of this virus. These brilliant minds are working on the most effective antiviral therapies and vaccines. We are working very, very hard. I have met many of the doctors that are doing it. These are doctors that are working so hard on vanquishing the virus.
content.zh: 美国食品药品监督管理局（FDA）对此感到满意。正如你所知，他们已经批准了它。他们迅速批准了它。原因是它已经上市很长时间了，他们知道它的副作用，也知道它的潜力。因此，我们已将其送往全国各地。我们储存了大约2900万剂，2900万剂。我们有很多。我们希望它有效。这源于科学界最聪明的头脑的目标。我们拥有科学界最聪明的头脑，但我们的目标也是消灭这场瘟疫，消灭这场祸害，消灭这种病毒。这些聪明的头脑正在研究最有效的抗病毒疗法和疫苗。我们正在非常非常努力地工作。我见过很多正在做这件事的医生。这些医生正在为消灭病毒而努力工作。

content.en: The human soul yearns for discovery. By unlocking the mysteries of the universe, we unlock truths within ourselves. That's true. Our journey into space will not only make us stronger and more prosperous, but will unite us behind grand ambitions and bring us all closer together. Wouldn't that be nice? Can you believe that space is going to do that? I thought politics would do that. (Laughter.) Well, we'll have to rely on space instead. Every launch into the skies is another step forward toward a future where our differences seem small against the vast expanse of our common humanity. Sometimes you have to view things from a distance in order to see the real truth. It is America's destiny to be at the forefront of humanity's eternal quest for knowledge and to be the leader amongst nations on our adventure into the great unknown. Space. A lotta room out there, right? [Buzz Aldrin interjects: To infinity and beyond!] This is infinity, it could be infinity, we don't really don't know, but it could be, there's gotta be something, but it could be infinity, right?
content.zh: 人类灵魂渴望探索。通过揭开宇宙的奥秘，我们也能解开自身内心的真理。这的确如此。我们的太空之旅不仅会让我们更加强大、更加繁荣，更会让我们团结起来，共同追求宏伟的目标，让我们更加紧密地联系在一起。那岂不是很棒？你能相信太空能做到这一点吗？我以为政治就能做到这一点。（笑声）好吧，我们只能依靠太空了。 每一次升空都是迈向未来的又一步，在那个未来，我们的差异在我们共同人性的浩瀚面前显得渺小。有时，你必须从远处观察事物，才能看到真正的真相。美国的命运就是站在人类永恒求知的前沿，并在我们探索未知领域的征程中成为各国的领袖。 太空。那里有很多空间，对吧？ [巴兹·奥尔德林插话：超越无限！] 这就是无限，也可能是无限，我们并非真的不知道，但可能是，肯定有某种东西，但也可能就是无限，对吧？

content.en: Finally, we must think big and dream even bigger. In America, we understand that a nation is only living as long as it is striving. We will no longer accept politicians who are all talk and no action, constantly complaining, but never doing anything about it. The time for empty talk is over. Now arrives the hour of action. Do not allow anyone to tell you that it cannot be done. No challenge can match the heart and fight and spirit of America. We will not fail. Our country will thrive and prosper again. We stand at the birth of a new millennium, ready to unlock the mysteries of space, to free the Earth from the miseries of disease, and to harness the energies, industries, and technologies of tomorrow. A new national pride will stir our souls, lift our sights, and heal our divisions.
content.zh: 最后，我们必须胸怀大志，梦想更大。在美国，我们深知，一个国家只有不断奋斗才能生存。我们不再接受那些光说不练、只会抱怨却从不付诸行动的政客。空谈的时代已经结束。现在是行动的时刻。不要让任何人告诉你这不可能。没有任何挑战能够与美国人民的勇气、斗志和精神相媲美。我们不会失败。我们的国家将再次繁荣昌盛。我们正站在新千年的开端，准备好解开太空的奥秘，让地球摆脱疾病的折磨，并驾驭未来的能源、产业和技术。新的民族自豪感将激励我们的灵魂，提升我们的视野，弥合我们的分歧。

content.en: From across the Earth, Americans are drawn to this place as though it were a part of our very soul. We come not only because of what they did here, we come because of who they were. They were young men with their entire lives before them. They were husbands who said goodbye to their young brides and took their duty as their fate. They were fathers who would never meet their infant sons and daughters because they had a job to do. And with God as their witness, they were going to get it done. They came wave after wave, without question, without hesitation, and without complaint.
